uh home I'm gonna present research on

it's work I've been doing with my

we've brought in her colleague Jamie
Lodge at Northeastern who's now my

in looking at how women executives
develop their careers we had a variety
of approaches we use our connections
with the ELC which you guys have heard
about today already and they were a
wonderful affinity group that allowed us
to reach out to several of their members
and we focused in this project on black
female executives and our question which
we probed the semi-structured interviews
at two time points in 2007 just before
the global financial crisis and then
again seven years later in 2014 we were
focused on what where the key
facilitators and impediments in their
career development paths and we found
several things of course with all of
that rich data we had 59 interviews that
we were able to replicate in 2014 and
but one thing that kept coming up that
kept being consistent across these
messages was intersectional invisibility
many of you have heard this term if you
haven't it describes the property
engagement of being into mult and two or
more subordinated identity groups and in
being that you'll find particularly for
black female executives which we focused
on they were extremely physically
visible they all kind of reference this
notion of being of standing out of being
noticed specifically for their black
femaleness right and so that kind of put
them under a spotlight but it also
provides a sense of invisibility and
there's lots of work that talks about
the paradox of invisibility laura has
worked on that recently with Robin and
others and this one ocean of being
cognitively invisible is something that
came out of what we were looking at
where in truth when you are on an
intersectional intersectional invisible
there's this notion of you're not the
prototypical black person which is a
black male and you're not the
prototypical woman which is a white
which is a white woman right and so they
were cognitive invisible they talked
about being overlooked they talked about
being ignored they talked about being
disregarded and so the sense of feeling
like I'm the best person for the job but
I'm not on your radar that came up
frequently so we asked ourselves so
because we had those two time points we
were able to see how are they dealing
with this across time and they all
talked about this early career stage
where they had to come to terms many for
the first time with being invisible they
had many of them had come from
privileged backgrounds had great
education but now they were being
overlooked and they needed to come to
terms with that and beyond that they
needed to find a way to move out of it
so we said well what helps there is
another line of research called a glass
cliff many of you have heard about it
it's this phenomena where you find high
risk high likelihood of failure
positions being given to people of color
or women or in our case people women of
color and so we said well do these
high-risk roles which are typically
framed as negative are they actually an
opportunity are they a way for black
women who are seeing themselves as being
constantly invisible giving them an
opportunity instead to be seen are they
using these to navigate their way to the
top and in fact that is exactly what we
found one woman described that it wasn't
until after she was willing to take a
risk that people were able to see her
and see her talents for what they were
black women executives were not only
willing but they were motivated they
were looking for those opportunities to
be out there to have their opportunity
to strike through and they found those
those opportunities they found that
they've got excited because it allowed
them to make a difference in the world
and most importantly it gave them
credibility the credibility they knew
that they needed to not only be seen but
be taken seriously so one woman said
that that opportunity gave her the
organizational credibility another woman
said there are some of the toughest jobs
you've got to really go in and make hey
but it allowed her to leapfrog a lot of
people and they saw her ascent as

on what allowed them to manage his glass

they are dangerous so one of the things

you need to know where the bodies are

who has your back right and aligned with

asking for what you need takes courage
many of these women said and so that was
